question.title: How to initialise list in class diagram?
question.body:
Eclipse Papyrus class diagram (Java). How can I define as a list to my attribute carList?

private List<Car> carList = new ArrayList<>();

I'm only able to define type as String, int, double, boolean etc..

answers.body:
The point of class diagrams is to show how types link together.

Thus, the whole point is to show how your take on the concept "Parking Lots" (I'm assuming your List<Car> carList; line is a field in class ParkingLot for the purposes of this explanation) are linked to your take on the concept of "Cars".

There's intentionally no option to say: "I leave it to the reader". Everything is meant to be defined in rigid, absolute terms - not the wishywishy 'who really knows what it means' of the english language. With one exception: Certain types are elevated as 'well, everybody does know what they mean / the language specification itself locks down in stone what they mean', and those are the ones you can use here - String, int, double, boolean, etc - that's where that list is coming from.

Car is not on that list.

Thus, what you have to do here is completely different from indicating "there is a carList, it is an attribute". You have no attribute at all. Instead, you show there is a 1..N relationship between cars and parking lots. Car is a 'box' in your diagram. ParkingLot is also a box. A line exists between the box, and a property of the line is that the 'Car' side has quantity nature 'N', and 'ParkingLot' has quantity nature '0..1' (or '1*' or any other way to express: a car may or may not be on a parking lot.. but it definitely cannot be simultaneously parked in two lots!)

This style of diagramming isn't programming. The point is to show in a quick to understand visual way how your various types relate to one another.

Having 2 out of every 4 boxes all draw a line to a box named 'String' is not going to make things visually clear at all, so you don't do that. But just having your field definition code in a little box, with boxes haphazardly scattered around a white canvas all on their own, also is completely pointless. Showing that ParkingLot is a thing, Car is a thing, and 'parking lots have many cars, though it could have 0', but a car can only ever be on at most one lot - that is the point.

If for the thing you're doing this doesn't sound useful then don't make a diagram at all.

question_comments.body: I have zero knowledge of Papyrus, but generally lists are a modelled with an association, aggregation or composition (1:N, M:N), not as an attribute on the class itself.
